item.title: After rocky start, can Biden recover in Year Two?
item.description: The U.S. presidency often involves major on-the-job training. Despite historic challenges, experts say Mr. Biden can still turn things around.
item.creator: Linda Feldmann

item.title: How should race be taught? New Mexico might have a model.
item.description: Home to sizable Hispanic and Native American populations, New Mexico wants to make sure its social studies curriculum is inclusive of a diverse student body. That includes rethinking how to teach sensitive history, such as the legacy of Spanish conquistadors.
item.creator: Cedar Attanasio

item.title: Senate filibuster lives on, halting Democrats' election bill
item.description: After a long and emotional debate on the U.S. Senate floor, Democratic senators Joe Manchin and Kyrsten Sinema passed on an attempt by other members of their party to nix the filibuster. That vote doomed the voting reform bill many Democrats see as a top priority.
item.creator: Lisa Mascaro

item.title: How expanded child tax credit aided these moms, changed economy
item.description: The expanded child tax credit last year slashed poverty and tested a model of cash aid widely shared to families, with no strings attached.
item.creator: Nick Roll

item.title: ‘Record speed and focus’: Biden’s judicial picks diversify bench
item.description: Among President Joe Biden’s most impressive achievements in his first year in office: the number and diversity of federal judges who have been confirmed.
item.creator: Henry Gass

item.title: Why major airlines are canceling US flights over 5G rollout
item.description: Major international airlines rushed to cancel or alter flights heading to the U.S. on Wednesday over concerns 5G mobile phone networks could interfere with aircraft technology. The Boeing 777 aircraft has been flagged for being particularly vulnerable.
item.creator: Jon Gambrell

item.title: Trump Organization under fire again as New York AG alleges fraud
item.description: Last year, the Manhattan district attorney charged the Trump Organization with tax fraud. Now Donald Trump’s records are under scrutiny again after the New York attorney general’s office found evidence that his company falsely valued assets for economic gain.
item.creator: Michael R. Sisak

item.title: Biden’s soft-power policy faces reality of Xi-Putin big-power world
item.description: President Biden’s foreign policy uses the language of soft power: alliances, democracy, moral authority. Can it adapt to the world of Xi and Putin?
item.creator: Howard LaFranchi

item.title: Trump wants Lisa Murkowski gone. A voting reform might save her.
item.description: The Alaska senator may escape the GOP base’s ire over her impeachment vote, thanks to a ballot measure ending partisan primaries.
item.creator: Simon Montlake

item.title: Historic Black churches receive $20 million donation on MLK Day
item.description: Some historic Black churches in the United States are set for demolition or struggling with inadequate funding. Now, a major donation launched on Martin Luther King Jr. Day will help them rebuild so that their congregations can continue to share their stories.
item.creator: Jay Reeves

item.title: On Martin Luther King Jr. Day, the battle over voting rights
item.description: In a Martin Luther King Jr. Day video speech, President Joe Biden called upon Americans to stand up for voting rights. But Mr. King's eldest son criticized Mr. Biden and Congress for failing to pass voting rights legislation.
item.creator: Staff

item.title: Texas synagogue hostages freed safely, British hostage-taker IDed
item.description: The hostage-taker, a British national, was killed Saturday night as FBI stormed the synagogue to free the hostages, who had been held for 10 hours.
creator: Jake Bleiberg
Eric Tucker
Michael Balsamo

item.title: The Supreme Court and vaccine mandates: Three questions
item.description: The Supreme Court Thursday blocked the Biden administration’s vaccine mandate for large employers. What happens now?
creator: Peter Grier
Noah Robertson

item.title: Trump 2024? Some supporters quietly hope he won’t run.
item.description: Although Republican voters strongly approve of Donald Trump, some fans would prefer a fresh face to pick up the former president’s mantle.
item.creator: Linda Feldmann

item.title: Ohio court scraps maps, showing promise for redistricting reform
item.description: In 2015, Ohio voters passed a constitutional amendment to make the redistricting process more bipartisan. This week, the state’s Supreme Court, in a decisions celebrated by voting rights advocates, cited the amendment when it nixed gerrymandered maps.
item.creator: Julie Carr Smyth

item.title: Supreme Court: US businesses not required to vaccinate or test
item.description: The court has concluded that the Biden administration overstepped its authority with a vaccine-or-test rule for U.S. businesses with at least 100 employees. The court is allowing the administration to proceed with a vaccine mandate for health care workers.
item.creator: Mark Sherman and Jessica Gresko

item.title: Rachel Balkovec makes baseball history as first female manager
item.description: Rachel Balkovec has been appointed the new manager of the New York Yankees’ Tampa Tarpons, making her the first female minor league baseball manager in history. She will oversee the development of future big leaguers for the world-renowned sports franchise.
item.creator: Jake Seiner

item.title: A step toward better justice: Prying open the ‘black box’ of plea deals
item.description: Efforts are underway to remove plea bargaining from the shadows, in hopes that more transparency will lead to changes that make the process more just.
item.creator: Henry Gass

item.title: Does 5G dangerously crowd the spectrum? Federal referee may help.
item.description: Concern over radio-spectrum crowding delayed 5G rollouts this month. But confirmation of a federal communications referee may help the process.
item.creator: Dwight A. Weingarten

item.title: Is murder upswing starting to abate? Some US cities see declines.
item.description: Although U.S. homicides rose again in 2021, the rate of increase slowed, and some cities saw outright declines. These two charts show the trends.
creator: Noah Robertson
Jacob Turcotte

item.title: Even as Omicron Wanes, New York City’s Teachers Are in a Holding Pattern
item.description: As absences persist, some schools are resigning themselves to remote learning.
item.keywords: New York City, Schools, Coronavirus, Pandemics, Teachers, Education
item.creator: Jessica Winter

item.title: Making Love in the Land of Oil Rigs
item.description: In Tabitha Lasley’s memoir, a study of the insular world of offshore oil rigs becomes an exhibit of the power dynamics between the men who work on them and the women they love on land.
item.keywords: Books, Memoirs, Britain, Oil Refineries, Offshore Drilling, Relationships
item.creator: Amber Medland

item.title: The Senate’s Dangerous Inability to Protect Democracy
item.description: The struggles of Angus King reflect the rise of Trumpism over centrism.
item.keywords: Senate, Centrism, Trumpism, Voting Rights, Elections, Maine
item.creator: David Rohde

item.title: Why President Biden Bet on a Senate That No Longer Exists
item.description: On the eve of the President’s first anniversary in office, members of the chamber he served for so long voted for paralysis over action.
item.keywords: Politics, Joe Biden, U.S. Senate, Voting Rights, Filibuster, Joe Manchin, Kyrsten Sinema
item.creator: Evan Osnos

item.title: The Outsized Entrepreneurial World of Trump Merchandise
item.description: At Trump’s first rally of the year, the former President wasn’t the only person selling a fantasy.
item.keywords: Donald Trump, Rallies, Campaigns, Election Fraud, Presidential campaign
item.creator: Rachel Monroe

item.title: Why You Can’t Resist Wordle
item.description: Unpacking the ingenious simplicity of the Internet’s favorite new word game.
item.keywords: Internet, Puzzles, Games, Fads, Entertainment
item.creator: Kyle Chayka

item.title: NBA YoungBoy and the Music Industry’s Unseen Stars
item.description: In 2020, a twenty-two-year-old rapper from Baton Rouge brought in nearly as much streaming revenue as Taylor Swift did. Why haven’t most people heard of him?
item.keywords: Music, Hip-Hop, Rap, Streaming, Spotify, YouTube
item.creator: Sheldon Pearce

item.title: Mapping Climate Grief, One Pixel at a Time
item.description: Norco, an indie adventure game about an oil town menaced by global warming, is a striking contribution to American landscape art.
item.keywords: Video Games, Tribeca Film Festival, Louisiana, Shell, Climate Change, Graphic Design
item.creator: Julian Lucas

item.title: The Rise of A.I. Fighter Pilots
item.description: Artificial intelligence is being taught to fly warplanes. Can the technology be trusted?
item.keywords: Technology, Airplanes, Military, Artificial Intelligence, Wars, Defense Department
item.creator: Sue Halpern

item.title: Jordan Thomas’s Army of Whistle-Blowers
item.description: The lawyer and his clients have made millions by exposing one Wall Street crime after another. But are they changing the industry?
item.keywords: Whistleblowers, Lawyers, Wall Street, Stock Market, Alzheimer’s, Prescription Drugs, Pharmaceutical Industry, Securities and Exchange Commission, Corporations, Pharmaceuticals
item.creator: Patrick Radden Keefe

item.title: A Daughter’s Quest to Free Her Father’s Killer
item.description: Katie Kitchen wanted to live up to her progressive ideals. Her own family tragedy presented a chance.
item.keywords: Prisoners, Race, Fathers, Robberies, Daughters, Murders, Survivors, Texas
item.creator: Eren Orbey

item.title: Thomas Mann’s Brush with Darkness
item.description: How the German novelist’s tormented conservative manifesto led to his later modernist masterpieces.
item.keywords: Thomas Mann, Literature, Books, Novels, Writers, Novelists, Manifestos, Colm Toibin
item.creator: Alex Ross

item.title: How One Woman Is Using Comedy to Speak Up About Palestinian Rights
item.description: The documentary “Reckoning with Laughter,” directed by Amber Fares, follows the Israeli comedian Noam Shuster as she returns home amid the coronavirus pandemic and quarantines with both Palestinians and Israelis.

item.title: The Personal and the Political at a Tunisian Salon
item.description: In Sarra El Abed’s “Ain’t No Time for Women,” a debate plays out at a hairdresser's as a group of women decide on their preferred Presidential candidates.

item.title: The Dehumanizing Theatre of the Parole Process
item.description: In “The Interview,” directed by Jon Miller and Zach Russo, formerly incarcerated people describe what it’s like trying to convince a group of strangers that they are more than the worst thing they ever did.

item.title: Joan Didion, the Observer; and Reviewing Biden, Year One
item.description: Hilton Als and Emma Cline on the late writer’s influence on generations of younger authors. And our correspondents assess the successes and failures of Biden’s first year.
item.category: Podcast / The New Yorker Radio Hour
item.keywords: Podcasts, Joan Didion, Writing, Joe Biden, Politics

item.title: One year in, Biden confronts the limits of his power
item.creator: Sahil Kapur
item.description: Democratic euphoria has faded as the president's ambitious goals have run headlong into the harsh realities of a 50-50 Senate, GOP opposition and a conservative Supreme Court.

text.#text: President Joe Biden exits after speaking in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building in Washington on April 21, 2021.

description.#text: President Joe Biden exits after speaking in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building in Washington on April 21, 2021.

item.title: Georgia prosecutor requests special grand jury in Trump election probe
item.creator: Charlie Gile and Teaganne Finn
item.description: Fulton County DA Fani Willis said some witnesses have refused to cooperate without subpoenas. A special grand jury would have the power to subpoena witnesses.

text.#text: Image: President Donald Trump speaks about early results from the 2020 U.S. presidential election in the East Room of the White House on Nov. 4, 2020.

description.#text: President Donald Trump speaks about early results from the 2020 U.S. presidential election in the East Room of the White House on Nov. 4, 2020.

item.title: Jan. 6 committee asks Ivanka Trump to give voluntary testimony
item.creator: Teaganne Finn and Leigh Ann Caldwell and Kyle Stewart and Ali Vitali and Haley Talbot and Peter Alexander
item.description: The committee said it has evidence that Ivanka Trump was "in direct contact" with her father on the day of the riot.

text.#text: White House Coronavirus Task Force Holds Daily Briefing

description.#text: President Donald Trump speaks as his daughter and senior adviser Ivanka Trump looks at the White House March 20, 2020.

item.title: FBI raid on Rep. Henry Cuellar's Texas home, office said to be tied to Azerbaijan
item.creator: Michael Kosnar and Tim Stelloh
item.description: Texas Rep. Henry Cuellar’s home and campaign office were raided as part of a federal investigation into to the former Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan.

text.#text: Image: Henry Cuellar

description.#text: Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas, speaks at a news conference on Capitol Hill on July 30.

item.title: Supreme Court declined to order Texas abortion case back to the original judge
item.description: The Supreme Court declined to order the Texas abortion case back to the original trial judge for further proceedings for a second time. NBC News’ justice correspondent Pete Williams reports on the most restrictive abortion law in the country known as S.B.8.

content.title: Supreme Court declined to order Texas abortion case back to the original judge

description.#text: The Supreme Court declined to order the Texas abortion case back to the original trial judge for further proceedings for a second time. NBC News’ justice correspondent Pete Williams reports on the most restrictive abortion law in the country known as S.B.8.

item.title: Trump's filing cabinets and Post-It notes: New York AG details new areas of interest in company probe
item.creator: Dareh Gregorian and Tom Winter
item.description: New York Attorney General Letitia James is seeking to gather more evidence in her multiyear investigation into the Trump Organization.

text.#text: Former President Donald Trump speaks during the Conservative Political Action Conference CPAC on July 11, 2021 in Dallas, Texas.

description.#text: Then-President Donald Trump speaks during the Conservative Political Action Conference CPAC, in Dallas, on July 11, 2021.

description.#text: Former President Donald Trump speaks during the Conservative Political Action Conference CPAC on July 11, 2021 in Dallas, Texas.

item.title: Top U.S. diplomat tries to clarify U.S., allied stance after Biden’s remarks on Russia
item.creator: Dan De Luce and Abigail Williams
item.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken vows “united” response to potential Russian attack on Ukraine after Biden comments raise doubts about transatlantic consensus.

text.#text: Secretary of State Antony Blinken, US Secretary of State speaks in Berlin on Jan. 20, 2022.

description.#text: Secretary of State Antony Blinken, US Secretary of State speaks in Berlin on Jan. 20, 2022.

item.title: I Am Vanessa Guillén Act brings 'historic' military reform as calls for justice persist
item.creator: Nicole Acevedo
item.description: As a new law provides new protections to victims of sexual violence, the family of slain Fort Hood soldier Vanessa Guillen await justice for her death.

text.#text: Image: Candles and flowers decorate a makeshift memorial for Vanessa Guillen on Aug. 14, 2020, in Houston.

description.#text: Candles and flowers decorate a makeshift memorial for Army Spc. Vanessa Guillén in Houston in August 2020.

item.title: 'Their pain is real': Blinken defends diplomats after CIA casts doubt on Havana Syndrome
item.creator: Josh Lederman and Ken Dilanian and Andrea Mitchell
item.description: Secretary of State Blinken defended diplomats who report suspected “Havana Syndrome” incidents, insisting “their pain is real" after a CIA report raised doubts.

text.#text: Image: U.S. Secretary of State Blinken in Berlin

description.#text: Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaks in Berlin on Thursday.

item.title: Federal inspectors allege Covid testing firm didn't put patients' names on specimens
item.creator: Laura Strickler
item.description: Federal documents allege Covid testing firm Center for Covid Control failed to put patient names on specimens or report results to state officials.

text.#text: Image: People gather outside a Center for Covid Control testing site in Calif.

description.#text: People gather outside a Center for Covid Control testing site in Calif.

description.#text: People stand in line for free Covid-19 testing at a temporary site set up by Center for Covid Control in Santa Fe, N.M., on Jan. 3.

item.title: 'There are no minor incursions': Biden's candid Putin predictions criticized in Kyiv and beyond
item.creator: Mo Abbas and Alexander Smith and Oksana Parafeniuk and Dan De Luce and Abigail Williams
item.description: President Joe Biden’s suggestion that Russian President Vladimir Putin will invade Ukraine and the West’s response could be more muted for a “minor” incursion drew swift criticism from Washington to Kyiv,

description.#text: President Biden answers questions during a news conference in the East Room of the White House, on Jan. 19, 2022.

description.#text: A Ukrainian soldier in the village of New York, formerly Novhorodske, near the front line of the ongoing conflict with Russian-backed separatists that has killed 14,000 people.

item.title: White House journalists reflect on President Biden’s first year
item.description: It has been a year since President Biden took office, now he looks ahead to his second year addressing Covid-19, the economy and his legislative agenda. NBC News’ Hallie Jackson is joined by NBC’s White House Unit Director Stacey Klein, White House Correspondent Mike Memoli, and Chief White House Correspondent Kristen Welker to discuss what this past year has been like on camera and behind the scenes.

content.title: White House journalists reflect on President Biden’s first year

description.#text: It has been a year since President Biden took office, now he looks ahead to his second year addressing Covid-19, the economy and his legislative agenda. NBC News’ Hallie Jackson is joined by NBC’s White House Unit Director Stacey Klein, White House Correspondent Mike Memoli, and Chief White House Correspondent Kristen Welker to discuss what this past year has been like on camera and behind the scenes.

item.title: White House on defense after Biden press conference
item.description: President Biden is now trying to clarify comments made during his news conference on what punishment Russia would face if it invaded Ukraine. As Biden marks one year in office, a new NBC News poll finds his approval rating is 43 percent.

content.title: White House on defense after Biden press conference

description.#text: President Biden is now trying to clarify comments made during his news conference on what punishment Russia would face if it invaded Ukraine. As Biden marks one year in office, a new NBC News poll finds his approval rating is 43 percent.

item.title: White House chief of staff on Biden’s Russia-Ukraine comments, pandemic handling
item.description: White House Chief of Staff Ron Klain tells Lester Holt that President Biden has “made his views very clear to President Putin” following Biden’s comments on a potential Russian incursion in Ukraine during a news conference on Wednesday.

content.title: White House chief of staff on Biden’s Russia-Ukraine comments, pandemic handling

description.#text: White House Chief of Staff Ron Klain tells Lester Holt that President Biden has “made his views very clear to President Putin” following Biden’s comments on a potential Russian incursion in Ukraine during a news conference on Wednesday.

item.title: Jan. 6 committee requests testimony from Ivanka Trump
item.description: The House committee investigating the Capitol attack has formally requested testimony from Ivanka Trump over a phone call they say Ivanka overheard between former President Trump and former Vice President Pence and her actions during the attack. A spokesperson for Ivanka says she publicly stated on Jan. 6 “the violence must stop immediately.”

content.title: Jan. 6 committee requests testimony from Ivanka Trump

description.#text: The House committee investigating the Capitol attack has formally requested testimony from Ivanka Trump over a phone call they say Ivanka overheard between former President Trump and former Vice President Pence and her actions during the attack. A spokesperson for Ivanka says she publicly stated on Jan. 6 “the violence must stop immediately.”

item.title: Black South Carolina voters speak on Biden’s promises
item.description: South Carolina Black Democratic voters turned out in force to help President Biden make it to the White House. One year later, NBC News’ Kristen Welker heads to state to speak with those voters about how the president is doing as an NBC News poll shows falling support among Black voters.

content.title: Black South Carolina voters speak on Biden’s promises

description.#text: South Carolina Black Democratic voters turned out in force to help President Biden make it to the White House. One year later, NBC News’ Kristen Welker heads to state to speak with those voters about how the president is doing as an NBC News poll shows falling support among Black voters.

item.title: Emily's List, NARAL pull support of Sinema over opposition to changing filibuster
item.creator: Teaganne Finn and Sahil Kapur
item.description: Abortion rights groups have traditionally resisted abolishing the filibuster in fear that it could backfire on them once conservatives regain control of Washington.

text.#text: Sen. Kyrsten Sinema, D-Ariz., speaks during Senate hearing on Oct. 19, 2021.

description.#text: Sen. Kyrsten Sinema, D-Ariz., speaks during Senate hearing on Oct. 19, 2021.

item.title: Black voters in South Carolina voice frustration with Biden's first year in office
item.creator: Rebecca Shabad and Kristen Welker
item.description: Some say they’re disappointed, in particular, with the failure by Democrats to pass key voting rights legislation in the Senate.

item.title: Anti-critical race theory activists have a new focus: Curriculum transparency
item.creator: Tyler Kingkade
item.description: Conservative activists want schools to post lesson plans online, but free speech advocates warn these policies could lead to more censorship in K-12 schools.

description.#text: Some conservative activists say the curriculum transparency effort is a potent strategic move to expose and root out progressive ideas from schools.

description.#text: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis called for a law to give parents the right to review the curriculums used in their children's schools.

item.title: Biden sends free tests and masks as Americans sour on pandemic response
item.creator: Alex Seitz-Wald
item.description: Almost two years into the pandemic, the government is shipping free tests and masks to millions of voters — will they thank the president in November?

item.title: Why Whales Don’t Choke
description: Scientists have discovered a new anatomical structure that allows lunge-feeding whales to take in massive amounts of water without choking.
A humpback whale lunge feeding off Vancouver Island in Canada.
item.creator: Sam Jones

item.title: U.S. Drops Its Case Against M.I.T. Scientist Accused of Hiding China Links
description: Gang Chen, a professor of mechanical engineering, was arrested a year ago, accused of concealing his affiliations with Chinese government institutions.
Gang Chen, an M.I.T. scientist, was arrested in 2021 as part of the China Initiative, a government anti-espionage effort that has come under criticism for singling out scientists of Chinese heritage.
item.creator: Ellen Barry and Katie Benner

item.title: A New Map of the Sun’s Local Bubble
item.description: At the edge of a vast region devoid of gas and dust, scientists find an explanation for “how all nearby star formation began.”
item.creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Sprawling Coral Reef Resembling Roses Is Discovered Off Tahiti
description: The reef, which is just under two miles long and is in “pristine” condition, was found by a team of divers mapping the ocean floor for UNESCO.
A coral reef resembling a bed of roses was discovered off the coast of Tahiti.
item.creator: Neil Vigdor

category.#text: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: ‘Major Discovery’ Beneath Antarctic Seas: A Giant Icefish Breeding Colony
item.description: Scientists discovered a mammoth nesting ground with an estimated 60 million icefish nests in the Weddell Sea.
item.creator: Sabrina Imbler

item.title: Sometimes, Life Stinks. So He Invented the Nasal Ranger.
description: For Chuck McGinley, an engineer who devised the go-to instrument for measuring odors, helping people understand what they smell is serious science.
Chuck McGinley with his Nasal Ranger, a design inspired by the shape of the Haleakala volcano in Hawaii.
item.creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin
item.credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times

item.title: Checking Privilege in the Animal Kingdom
description: Researchers say the human concepts of intergenerational wealth and inequality are useful for studying some animals’ behavior.
Check your privilege, squirrel.
item.creator: Elizabeth Preston

item.title: How European Royals Once Shared Their Most Important Secrets
description: Recent research highlights the use of letterlocking techniques by Queen Elizabeth, Catherine de’ Medici and Mary Queen of Scots.
A letter from Mary Queen of Scots, sent on Feb. 8, 1587, to Henry III, king of France. The letter was written and locked just hours before Mary was executed for treason.
item.creator: William J. Broad

category.#text: Elizabeth I, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Deborah Nickerson, Pioneering Genome Researcher, Dies at 67
item.description: Using the Human Genome Project as her guide, she helped find genes responsible for cardiovascular disease, autism and a rare disorder called Miller syndrome.
item.creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Kidneys From a Genetically Altered Pig Are Implanted in a Brain-Dead Patient
item.description: Surgeons at the University of Alabama at Birmingham said they hoped to start clinical trials with kidney patients later this year.
item.creator: Roni Caryn Rabin

item.title: Predictions Favored Solar Over Wind Power. What Happened?
item.description: One lesson: Renewable technology benefits from early, consistent government support.
item.creator: Lois Parshley

item.title: ‘Build Back Better’ Hit a Wall, but Climate Action Could Move Forward
description: Some Democrats want to forge ahead with a stand-alone climate bill, but their solution could mean abandoning other parts of President Biden’s agenda.
“I think it’s clear that we would be able to get support for the $500 billion plus for energy and the environment,” President Biden said of Congress on Wednesday.
item.creator: Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman

item.title: Most ‘Havana Syndrome’ Cases Unlikely Caused by Foreign Power, C.I.A. Says
description: A report concluded that most cases have environmental or medical causes, but the government remains focused on investigating two dozen incidents that remain unexplained.

About 1,000 cases of the mysterious illness that initially appeared at the U.S. Embassy in Havana have been reported, but of those, the C.I.A. is now focusing on about two dozen unexplained incidents.
item.creator: Julian E. Barnes

item.title: Why Are Men More Likely to Die of Covid? It’s Complicated.
description: Sex differences in Covid death rates vary widely from state to state, suggesting they are rooted in behavior as well as biology.
A Covid-19 patient in the intensive care unit of a hospital in La Mesa, Calif.
item.creator: Azeen Ghorayshi

item.title: Sara McLanahan, Who Studied Single Motherhood, Dies at 81
item.description: A Princeton sociologist and a single mother herself, she brought her own experience to her wide body of scholarly work.
item.creator: Annabelle Williams

item.title: In Sewage, Clues to Omicron’s Surge
description: Tracking the virus in wastewater is helping some cities and hospitals respond to the most recent wave of the coronavirus, but a more coordinated national effort is needed, experts say.
Workers in Monaco took sewage water samples to detect coronavirus concentration in the area in 2021.
item.creator: Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler

item.title: How Anxiety Can Benefit Us
item.description: There are several benefits to having an internal alarm system, experts say.

item.title: New Research Shows How Health Risks to Children Mount as Temperatures Rise
description: The first nationwide study on rising temperatures and younger Americans found that hotter days were associated with more visits to emergency rooms.
A misting station in Queens in August. National research shows that children face particular dangers during heat waves.
item.creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin

item.title: Searching for Pfizer’s Paxlovid Pills When Mom Got Covid
description: The experience showed how hard it is for many people to get potentially lifesaving treatments.
Mary Ann Neilsen, the author’s mother, holding her last Paxlovid pills while recovering from Covid-19.
item.creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Administration Announces Plan to Spend Billions to Prevent Wildfires
description: The plan is an expensive one, but it is only partially funded.
The Caldor fire in Eldorado National Forest near Pollock Pines, Calif., last year.

item.credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

item.title: Here’s What Scientists Know About the Tonga Volcano Eruption
description: The explosion probably won’t cool the planet as some previous eruptions have done, but it could affect weather in the short term.
The Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’apai volcano, off the coast of Tonga, on Friday.
item.creator: Henry Fountain

item.title: After Tonga's Volcano Eruption, Worries Grow About Covid Exposure
description: Aid workers risk bringing in a virus Tonga has so far kept out. But there are more immediate problems, as its government confirmed in its first statement since the disaster.
Vista de una densa caída de ceniza en Nomuka, Tonga, el lunes

item.title: In Arkansas, Trans Teens Await an Uncertain Future
item.description: Even as the medical community grapples with how best to provide care to transgender adolescents, some states seek to ban it outright.

item.credit: Liz Sanders for The New York Times

item.title: A California City Is Overrun by Crows. Could a Laser Be the Answer?
description: In a move befitting its Silicon Valley setting, the city of Sunnyvale, Calif., will aim a laser at 1,000 birds that have overwhelmed the downtown area during the pandemic.
Crows fly near downtown Sunnyvale, Calif.
item.creator: Alyssa Lukpat

category.#text: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

item.title: The Eerie, Lunar Nothingness of Namibia’s Skeleton Coast
description: The stretch of coastline in southwest Africa is a strange and beautiful reminder that, in the end, we are powerless against nature and time.
The C34 highway, along Namibia’s coast, is barely distinguishable from the surrounding desert.
item.creator: Genna Martin

item.title: The C.D.C.’s New Challenge? Grappling With Imperfect Science
description: The Omicron coronavirus variant is moving much faster than researchers can, worsening a longstanding problem: The agency must make tough decisions with scant data.
Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the C.D.C. director, right, and Dr. Anthony Fauci of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, during a Senate hearing in November.

item.title: How The mRNA Vaccines Were Made: Halting Progress and Happy Accidents

item.title: Ancient 'scepters' were actually straws for communal boozing, researchers say
item.creator: Tom Metcalfe
item.description: Silver and gold tubes unearthed in an ancient tomb in southern Russia and long thought to be ceremonial staffs were, in fact, the earliest-known drinking straws.

text.#text: An artist's conception shows men drinking beer from a communal vessel.

description.#text: An artist's conception shows men drinking beer from a communal vessel.

description.#text: A schematic drawing of the set of "scepters" from the Maikop kurgan.

text.#text: The "scetpers" from the Maikop kurgan

description.#text: The "scepters" from the Maikop kurgan are perforated at one end by slits to serve as strainers, and the tubes have jointed segments. It's thought that long seams along each of the tubes were sealed by soldering them.

item.title: As climate warms, athletes flag the dangers of manmade snow
item.creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A British skier crashes through wooden fencing on a downhill corner and slams into a pole, breaking his leg.

text.#text: Norway's Vibeke Skofterud, left, escapes a crash involving Sweden's Norgren Johansson, right, and Poland's Paulina Maciuszek in the women's 15-kilometer pursuit cross country skiing event at Whistler Olympic Park on Feb. 19, 2010, at the 2010 Vancouver Olympic Winter Games in Whistler, B.C. Many top Nordic skiers and biathletes say crashes are becoming more common as climate change reduces the availability of natural snow, forcing racers to compete on tracks with the manmade version.

description.#text: Norway's Vibeke Skofterud, left, escapes a crash involving Sweden's Norgren Johansson, right, and Poland's Paulina Maciuszek in the women's 15-kilometer pursuit cross country skiing event at Whistler Olympic Park on Feb. 19, 2010, at the 2010 Vancouver Olympic Winter Games in Whistler, B.C.

text.#text: An artist’s impression of a red supergiant star

description.#text: An artist’s impression of a red supergiant star in the final year of its life emitting a tumultuous cloud of gas. It suggests that at least some of these stars undergo significant internal changes before they go supernova.
